titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Pittsburgh Peace Institute Records, 1984-1997 AIS.1998.01
titlestmt.author: Jennifer Needham.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-06-11 09:38:51 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The Pittsburgh Peace Institute, which existed between 1984-1997, advocated nonviolent strategies to combat violence and oppression. The organization brought its message to the community and its youth, through classes, workshops, and school programs. The collection consists of board business, financial records, newsletters, publications, educational materials, and materials from its Making Choices program for youth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Pittsburgh Peace Institute Records date from 1984 to 1997 and document the activities of the organization which advocated methods nonviolence on an international, national, and local level. The collection is organized into three series: Administrative, Education and Outreach, and Audio and Visual Materials. Each series is organized alphabetically according to subject matter and chronologically within specific subjects. Where a significant amount of material exists, a separate section has been created within the series.

The Administrative series includes records pertaining to board business, committee activities, staff records, and financial records, including fundraising activities. The Education and Outreach series includes records pertaining to the PPI's abolitionist tour, book talk program, courses offered, Dealing With Prejudice program, workshops and the numerous publications the institute was involved in. A majority of the series is devoted to the Making Choices program, which were committed to teaching nonviolent problem solving to youth. The Audio and Visual Materials series includes photographs of program pilots and workshops and video featuring recordings of the Making Choices pilot program, and a documentary of the underground railroad in Western Massachusetts.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: The Pittsburgh Peace Institute (PPI) was a private non-profit organization founded in 1984 in order to respond to the unavoidable increase in violence on a local, national, and international level. The institute was dedicated to providing community based education on the uses of nonviolence with an emphasis on programming for children and youth.

In order to combat adolescent violence and promote diversity, the institute developed two successful anti-violence programs for schools: Making Choices, developed for middle school students, and Dealing with Prejudice, for high school students.

The institute also offered a number of courses and workshops for adults that ranged from life skills, international issues, social justice and violence prevention. Additionally, the institute published The Peace Educator and The Subject is Nonviolence newsletters, as well as the books: Hammer of Justice: Molly Rush and Plowshares Eight; Simpleton Story: A Fairy Tale for the Nuclear Age; and Making Choices: A Program for Youth, which was used in conjunction with the Making Choices program in schools.

The PPI was originally located between the neighborhoods of Squirrel Hill and Shadyside on Wightman Ave., before moving in 1990 to the East Liberty Presbyterian Church. After almost 15 years of working with the community, the organization dissolved in 1997.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Jennifer Needham in November-December 2010.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Janet Seltman in June 1999.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series documents the internal activities of the institute. The material dates from 1984-1997 and is arranged alphabetically by subject and then chronologically within the specific subjects. Much of the series is divided into sections in which a significant amount of material concerning a specific subject exists. The material includes administrative records, board member biographies, board business, committees business, and financial including fundraising activities.

did.unittitle: Staff file for Siegal, Eleanor R.
Staff Personnel Policies, Job Descriptions, and Letter of Agreement

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series dates from 1984-1997 and includes records pertaining to the various educational and community outreach programs that the Pittsburgh Peace Institute was involved in. The series is divided alphabetically into subjects and then chronologically within each subject. Much of the series is divided into sections in which a significant amount of material concerning a specific subject exists. Included are materials pertaining to the Abolitionist Tour, announcements and fliers, bibliographies of certain subjects of concern to the institute, book talk records, and the variety of courses and workshops offered. The series includes a significant amount of materials pertaining to the development and implementation of peace programs for schools, like "Making Choices," "Beyond Columbus," and "Dealing with Prejudice." Also included are the variety of publications the institute was involved in, for instance their newsletters: The Peace Educator andThe Subject is Nonviolence, as well as the small and large publications the PPI produced, likeThe Hammer of Justice and Making Choices, used with the Making Choices program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series dates from 1992-1997 and includes photographs of meeting, panels, and classroom pilot projects, as well as VHS tapes of a pilot Making Choices class and documentary of the underground railroad in Pittsburgh, which features interviews with PPI's John Burt.
